Expectation1: Maintain a safe and O39ean work environment.
Situation1: At the end of the shift, it's time for the routine sweep-up of your designated work area.
Expectation2: Organize and participate in peaceful protests to raise awareness about social issues.
Situation2: Police have just begun to unexpectedly block the exits of the protest area, and you must immediately help coordinate a safe response.
Story: The clang of metal echoed as I swept dust and debris into a pile, my back aching from the day’s labor. The foreman’s voice rang out, reminding us that a clean site meant a safe site—no exceptions. I glanced at the clock; my shift was nearly over, but my phone buzzed urgently in my pocket. A message from the activist group flashed on the screen: “Police are blocking exits—need help now!” My heart pounded. I was supposed to help coordinate a safe, calm response, to protect my friends and the cause we all believed in. But here, on the site, I was expected to finish the sweep, to leave the area spotless for the next crew. If I left now, I’d be letting my coworkers down, risking safety and maybe even my job. If I stayed, I’d be abandoning people who counted on me to keep them safe. The broom felt heavy in my hands as I stood frozen, torn between two worlds that demanded all of me at once.
